statement.p: Explain why any orthonormal collection of vectors is linearly independent.

How does one compute the coordinates of a vector v in an orthonormal basis u_1,\ldots,u_n? Explain why this procedure is generally more efficient than finding coordinates in an non-orthonormal basis. (Caution: any vector in an orthonormal basis u_1, \ldots, u_n has length 1, so in the formula for the ith coordinate of v you need not divide by u_i \cdot u_i)

statement.p:
Let x and y be nonzero orthogonal vectors in \R^n. Which of the following are true?
x \cdot y =0
\| x-y \|^2 = \|x\|^2 + \|y\|^2
proj_{\Span(x)}(y)=0
proj_{\Span(y)}(x)=0
[MIT OCW] What is the projection of the vector \vec{1 1 1} \in \R^3 onto the plane 3x-4y+z=0?

answer.p: The vector \vec{1 1 1} lies on the plane 3x-4y+z=0, so its projection onto that plane is simply \vec{1 1 1} again.

statement.p: [MIT OCW] Suppose \{v_1, \ldots, v_k\} is an orthonormal set of vectors in \R^n. What happens when you apply Gram-Schmidt process to this set? Why?

answer.p: The Gram-Schmidt procedure does not modify orthormal sets of vectors \{v_1, ldots, v_k\} in \R^n. Let us prove this statement by induction on k. If k=1, it is obvious. Consider an orthonormal set \{v_1, \ldots, v_{k+1}\} of k+1 vectors in \R^n. We first apply GS to the set \{v_1, \ldots, v_k\}. By the induction hypothesis, this set stays unchanged. Then we compute to the orthogonal projection of v_{k+1} onto the space spanned by v_1, ldots, v_k. Since v_{k+1} is orthogonal to v_i for i=1 \ldots k, this projection is 0. Therefore, GS procedure does not change the set \{v_1, \ldots, v_{k+1}\}.
